708203f-a.text:
Fourth Ave., east side, north from East 19th to 23rd Streets, showing two churches and a hotel, prominent of which is the All Souls Unitarian Church at the S.W. corner of East 20th Street. Occupying the S.E. and N.E. corners of East 21st Street respectively are the New Amsterdam Hotel and Calvary P.E. Church. The Unitarian Church at which George P. Baker, Joseph Choate, William Cullen Bryant and Peter Cooper were worshipers, was demolished in 1929 and the property sold for a Club hotel which never materialized and the site vacant since. The congregation meanwhile moved into a newly constructed edifice at Lexington Ave. and East 80th Street. According to the New York Times of March 26, 1938 a new 6-story apartment house will shortly rise here at a cost of $600,000.

1906.
Brown Brothers.

Neg #3222.

708201f-a.text:
West side of Fourth Avenue, looking north from 19th Street.

1906.

Brown Brothers, Photographer.

708202f-a.text:
Fourth Avenue, east side, from 19th to 22nd Streets.  In the block from 20th to 21st Streets may be seen the McClure and Eagle Buildings, and beyond them, on the N.E. corner of 21st Street, is Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church.
February 21, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.
